Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Hybrid Objects and Intercultural Assemblages in Colonial Louisiana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the guidance of Dr. Shannon Lee Dawdy, Ms. Lauren Zych will analyze handmade ceramics collected from colonial sites in Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. During the eighteenth century these sites were part of the Louisiana colony, which encompassed the Mississippi river and its tributaries from Canada south to the Gulf of Mexico. Claimed for the French crown in 1682, the colony was eventually divided between England and Spain, and subsequently acquired by the United States in the Louisiana Purchase of 1803. The ceramics under investigation are important because, unlike the majority of ceramics from colonial sites, they are coarse and handmade rather than mass-produced. They are also associated with two groups of people - Native Americans and enslaved Africans - whose experiences and perspectives are severely underrepresented, if not completely absent, from historic accounts of the colonial era. Because these ceramics were recovered from colonial contexts, rather than Indian villages or slave cabins, they reveal complex and multi-faceted relationships between Native Americans, Africans, and European colonists that deserve further investigation. Ms. Zych's research will combine archaeological evidence with data from historic and ethnohistoric records in order to explore the nature and extent of intercultural relations during the colonial period.

The European colonization of the Americas had dramatic, and often unforeseen, consequences for indigenous tribes, as well as for thousands of African people forcibly enslaved and transported across the Atlantic. The broad strokes of their stories may be familiar - physical and cultural dislocation, enslavement, extreme poverty, starvation, and death - but scholars agree that this singular vision, glosses over considerable variation in the African and Indian experience of colonization. This project will use material culture, primarily in the form of handmade ceramics, to shed new light on group interaction in colonial Louisiana during the eighteenth century.
Using a combination of traditional and experimental archaeological techniques, this project will analyze the production, consumption, meaning and use of handmade ceramics in colonial contexts. Descriptive, typological, and comparative analysis will reveal the social, material and political contexts most often associated with handmade ceramics. Advanced forms of chemical analysis, including neutron activation analysis (NAA) and laser ablated-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS), will be used to identify the geographic origins of non-local vessels. Combined with insights gleaned from critical use of historic documents, these analyses will reveal the complex nature of the relations between colonists, Native Americans, and African people in a century characterized by radical transformations in both lifeways and political regimes.

This research is broadly conceived and designed to hold significance for multiple audiences. It will highlight the social, cultural and historical contributions of peoples whose role in the formation of America is poorly understood and frequently undervalued. To insure that this research makes an impact outside the discipline, the results will be presented to both academic and general audiences through a combination of public lectures, professional presentations, and peer-reviewed publications. The completed dissertation will be available through a subscription-based database, while raw data generated through this research will be available online in an open forum expressly designed for data-sharing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was designed to investigate the relationships between European colonists, Africans, and Native Americans in Louisiana from 1718 to 1803. Drawing upon archaeological data from six colonial sites in the city of New Orleans, this project focused primarily on the analysis of coarse, handmade and low-fired earthenware. Variously labeled “prehistoric,” “aboriginal,” or “colonoware” vessels, these ceramics are traditionally associated with Native Americans and/or people of African descent, and, when originating in distinctly Euro-colonial contexts, they provide the most abundant form of material evidence for cross-cultural interaction in this period. With NSF support, more than 1000 vessel fragments from colonial New Orleans were examined, generating new data on paste, temper, surface treatment, decoration, use wear, and vessel form. In addition, more than 300 sherds from New Orleans and relevant comparative sites were submitted for advanced forms of chemical and mineralogical analysis, including neutron activation analysis (NAA), ceramic petrography, and laser ablated-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS).

The results of these analyses reveal a remarkably diverse array of intercultural relationships at play during the eighteenth century. Early colonial deposits from the founding years, ca. 1718-1720, suggest that Euro-colonial and African labor was used to build temporary huts in a local Native American style. An open public space near a colonial-era church produced a high proportion of Native American imports and other artifacts that suggest the presence of an undocumented multicultural market. Excavations at a private household revealed that the occupants – which included African and Native American slaves – maintained long-term relationships with multiple local and non-local Native groups. A nearby convent acquired mostly local bowls, while a colonial-era fort is associated with several unique jars that may have a West African origin.

The diversity apparent here suggests that no single model of colonial interaction can account for the range of relationships evident in the archaeological record. The chemical and mineralogical data – now available for nearly 60 archaeological sites in five states and two continents – is particularly compelling. When analyzed within a comparative framework, it reveals significant differences in local and non-local group relations that vary from site to site and change over time. When combined with additional lines of evidence from historic documents, ethnohistoric accounts, and related archaeological investigations, these data provide powerful new evidence which suggests that Native American and African people played a much more complex and nuanced role in the founding and establishment of New Orleans than previously believed.
